Source   Edit  

DSL Helpers to build Grammar Rules easily

This module provides concise procedures to construct the AST of your grammar. Usage: import treestand/dsl rule: seq(sym("A"), choice(str("b"), patt("d+")))

Imports

rules

Procs

proc choice(rules: varargs[Rule]): Rule {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Matches ONE of the provided rules (Ordered Choice / Alternation). Example: choice(str("true"), str("false")) Source   Edit   
proc field(name: string; r: Rule): Rule {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Assigns a field name to the rule. Used for generating named fields in the resulting CST/AST nodes. Source   Edit   
proc opt(r: Rule): Rule {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Matches zero or one occurrence of the rule (Optional). Effectively choice(r, blank). Source   Edit   
proc patt(p: string): Rule {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Matches a Regular Expression pattern. Example: patt("\\w+") matches identifiers. Source   Edit   
proc prec(p: int; r: Rule): Rule {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Assigns a static precedence level to the rule. Higher values bind tighter. Used to resolve shift/reduce conflicts (e.g. operator precedence). Source   Edit   
proc prec_dynamic(p: int; r: Rule): Rule {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Assigns Dynamic Precedence. Helps resolve GLR conflicts at runtime by favoring paths with higher dynamic precedence. Source   Edit   
proc prec_left(p: int; r: Rule): Rule {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Assigns Left Associativity and precedence. Example: 1 + 2 + 3 -> (1 + 2) + 3. Source   Edit   
proc prec_right(p: int; r: Rule): Rule {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Assigns Right Associativity and precedence. Example: a = b = c -> a = (b = c). Source   Edit   
proc rep(r: Rule): Rule {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Matches one or more occurrences of the rule (Repeat). Example: rep(sym("digit")) matches one or more digits. Source   Edit   
proc seq(rules: varargs[Rule]): Rule {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Matches a sequence of rules in order. Example: seq(str("func"), sym("block")) Source   Edit   
proc str(s: string): Rule {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Matches a literal string. Example: str("if") matches the keyword "if". Source   Edit   
proc sym(name: string): Rule {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
References another named rule (Non-Terminal) in the grammar. Example: sym("expression") matches the "expression" rule. Source   Edit   
proc token(r: Rule): Rule {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Marks the rule as a Lexical Token. The parser treats tokens as atomic units; their internal structure is handled by the Lexer. Use this for things like identifiers, numbers, or keywords that shouldn't be parsed recursively by the parser logic. Source   Edit
